We propose to conduct a randomized clinical trial to test the efficacy of the Army Health mobile application in improving psychological resiliency and preventing suicidal ideation in National Guard and Reserve soldiers. The primary objective of the study is to test the efficacy of the Army Health app in reducing behavioral health problems and improving overall resiliency, as well as improving mental and physical health outcomes.
The study will run for a period of one year, with six months of pre-treatment baseline data collection followed by one year of treatment. A one-month washout period will also occur at study conclusion to enable participants to continue using the app if they wish. The study population will consist of 2,000 eligible participants (1,000 per arm). The target recruitment timeframe is 24 months.
After obtaining institutional and local IRB approval, a study flyer will be distributed to all personnel at a randomized centralized location, soliciting participants and providing study information. Eligible participants who express interest will be contacted by telephone to discuss study participation, answer questions about the study, and screen for exclusion/inclusion criteria.
Once all required forms (IRB, consent, etc.) are obtained, participants will be randomized to the intervention or control arm using a central secure web-based randomization system. Allocation concealment will occur at the centralized, investigational drug supply center, and participants will receive an alert notification upon randomization.
Intervention/Treatment:
The intervention is the Army Health mobile application, which will be made available to participants after randomization, and includes a range of tools, including health tracking, skill-building exercises, mood monitoring, and connectivity with a healthcare professional or coach. Certainly! The full study design will be as follows: This is an open-label randomized controlled non-blinded study in Khatamullah hospital. Patients between 18 to 70 years of age, who are scheduled to undergo chemotherapy that may cause nausea and vomiting, will be screened for eligibility. Patients will be randomized to one of two treatment arms 3 days prior to the commencement of chemotherapeutic agents. The first treatment arm consists of ondansetron given every 3 days, in combination with aprepitant and dexamethasone given on the morning of the first day of chemotherapy. The second treatment arm consists of ondansetron given every week, in combination with aprepitant and dexamethasone at bedtime on the night before the first day of chemotherapy. Treatment will continue for 5 days each cycle of chemotherapy (on the first day of chemotherapy to the fourth day after chemotherapy). The Primary end-point is complete control of the emesis. Other endpoints include time to first emetic episode, numbers of emetic episodes, responder analysis (yes/no response), change in body weight, incidence of adverse effects and the cost-effectiveness of the two arms.

Example of a P2 study focused on diagnostic and therapeutic implications
P2: Detailed study design for diagnostic and therapeutic implications
Title P2: Study Design for Diagnostic and Therapeutic Implications
Introduction Urine flow rate could be used to predict patients who are most likely to benefit from a certain treatment option for lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). A prospective study is needed to demonstrate the usefulness of urine flow rate measurement as a screening tool for predicting response to treatment. Therefore, the following hypothesis is being tested:
H0: In patients with LUTS and anuria, urine flow rate in the voiding phase of the urine flow meter will not be associated with patient symptoms as measured by the IPSS.
H1: In patients with LUTS, urine flow rate in the voiding phase of the urine flow meter will be associated with patient symptoms as measured by the IPSS.
Study population Patients with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) from either benign prostatic hyperplasia, overactive bladder, or chronic prostatitis / chronic pelvic pain syndrome
Control strategy This is a longitudinal cohort/observational study. Urine flow rate and IPSS will be assessed at baseline and at one month follow-up.
Timing Study visits will be at 8-week intervals. Patients who demonstrate an increase in urine flow rate of greater than 0.5 mL/sec from baseline to follow-up will be followed for another 8 weeks.
Outcome measures 1. Urine flow rate in the voiding phase (1st 30 seconds) of urine flow meter 2. International prostate symptom score (IPSS)
Brief description of the study study population and intervention (detailed further below) study endpoint(s)/outcome(s). study period: timings and duration.
Sample size Determine number of patients required by power analysis. A two-sample t test, assuming a pooled standard deviation of urine flow rate (SD = 200 mL/sec)

No intervention The "standard care" arm represents usual care from the SPC, which includes monitoring, dietary and mobility support, and usual medical care. The "no change" arm represents a period of relative inactivity during hospitalization during the data collection window. The "increased activity" arm requires subjects to engage in some form of extra activity such as physical and/or cognitive rehabilitation. model_response:
Observational study phases may vary, but here's a general definition from the FDA: Phase 0 - the drug first meets preclinical testing standards and the safety and dosage of the drug are tested in a small number of healthy patients or a small number of patients with the disease of interest. Phase I - the drug is tested in a small group of healthy volunteers to determine safety, dosage, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and adverse effects. Phase II - the drug is tested on individuals with the disease of interest to confirm its safety, effectiveness, and dosage. Phase III - the drug is tested on an expanded group of patients with the disease of interest, in a controlled comparison with a placebo and under double blind conditions (neither the patient nor the doctor knows whether the patient is getting the drug or a placebo). Phase 4 - post marketing trials or surveillance studies in large numbers of people to study long-term effects and any side effects of the medicine. 
How's that? Could you please provide me with the outcome of your study?

That would definitely be helpful. Please go ahead.  The inclusion criteria for participating in the observational study would be patients with rheumatoid arthritis between the ages of 18-85 years, diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis by a rheumatologist, no history of autoimmune conditions, and no pregnancy or plans to become pregnant in the next 16 weeks. The exclusion criteria for not participating in the observational study would be current or recent active infection, currently being treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and participation in another clinical trial. Do you have any other important details that should be included in the inclusion and exclusion criteria?

Let's review the inclusion and exclusion criteria from the previous example with some additional explanations. We can see that inclusion criteria 1, 2, and 3 are the same. However, we did state that the first criterion was altered to include burns received within the last 7 days. The reason for this is to ensure that the burns do not get older and the wounds start to heal. By having an inclusion period of only 7 days, it will restrict the study to new burns only.
The exclusion criteria were also altered. Exclusion criterion 4 was changed from no history of renal or liver disease to no recent surgery in the last 7 days. Because surgery in the last 7 days can cause a change in renal or liver function, it was decided to exclude any patient who has had surgery in the last 7 days. Exclusion criterion 5 was changed from no history of metabolic disease to no history of psychiatric disease. Psychiatric disease may alter hemodynamics and thus, affect the readings taken while the patient is undergoing fluid resuscitation. By excluding patients with a history of psychiatric disease, it ensures a baseline measure of hemodynamics can be taken prior to fluid resuscitation.
The next section will cover how to define the specific aims of the study.

The primary outcome will be survival. Secondary outcomes will include hospital stay duration, complication rates, and quality-of-life assessments. Additional details regarding the study design can be provided upon request.

Study Drug: QL1706H Drug Class: Oral and Injectable QL1706H
Objectives: The primary objective is to characterize the safety, maximum tolerated dose (MTD), pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. The secondary objectives are to evaluate anti-tumor activity of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors and to evaluate the pharmacodynamics of QL1706H in patients with solid tumors.
Study design: This is a Phase 1/1b, multi-center, open-label study planned to be conducted in approximately 64 patients with advanced solid tumors.
Study Population: Males or females >/=18 years of age with measurable or evaluable solid tumors, who have been treated at least 4 weeks or 5 days after the last treatment with an investigational drug or device, and who have had disease progression after at least one lines of chemotherapy, including a PD-(L)1/EGFr antibody (at the discretion of the investigator) or recurrence following curative surgery.
Study Duration: Maximum of approximately 75 weeks.
Study Plan: Patients are initially assigned to escalating dose levels of QL1706H orally or intravenously once every 21 days in a 3 + 3 dose escalation design. Each dose level will consist of three patients for QL1706H intravenous dosing and six patients for QL1706H oral dosing. If three of six patients experience dose limiting toxicity at a dose level, that level will be considered the MTD. Excellent! Our inclusion and exclusion criteria have been established. Let's move on to sample size estimation.
Sample size estimation is an important part of protocol development and an integral component of protocol review. Estimating the sample size for a clinical trial requires several factors, including the effect size, precision, alpha level, and beta error rate. Alpha and beta rates are critical because they determine the statistical power of the study. In general, the alpha level is usually set at 0.05, and the beta error rate is set at 0.20.
Once we have the alpha and beta errors established, we need to determine the power of the study. Power refers to the probability of detecting a treatment effect if it exists. For example, if the power is 0.80, it means that if the treatment does have an effect, we will detect it 80% of the time. How many participants we need to include in the study depends on what we are measuring and the precision of the measurements. A clinical trial may need to recruit several hundred or even a few thousand participants to be able to detect a treatment effect with sufficient precision.
How long it takes to reach a targeted sample size depends on the study design, the drug under study, and the effect size. In some cases, it may take several years to reach the sample size required. However, it's important to be honest about time requirements in clinical trial design to avoid delays and to make sure the study does not exceed the funds available or the participants' willingness to participate.
The sample size estimation is critical because it helps us determine whether the study is likely to be successful. Poorly designed studies can waste money, time, and resources, whereas well-designed studies save them. By carefully considering the sample size in the protocol planning stage, we can increase the chances of a successful clinical trial.

With the above inclusion/exclusion criteria, it looks like we have a well-rounded clinical study protocol. 3.1.2.2 Selection of Patients If we were to ask whether it is a randomized cohort or a cross-sectional cohort, randomized cohort is when you have the groups randomized to some therapy or control group and you have a follow-up, followed by some intervention and then some other follow-up. Cross-sectional cohort would be where you just select people at the beginning, and then you follow them for some time course, but they are not randomly assigned to different groups. So we will be doing a randomized clinical trial in a cohort fashion so the subjects are sequentially placed into either the treatment and control arm or the other way around. Subjects will be randomly ascertained from the population of interest by our sponsor's physician and from there they will be referred to a study physician for screening. Screening will involve assessment of inclusion/exclusion criteria and randomization. After randomization, subjects will begin their respective assigned interventions. Outcomes will be measured as pre-specified. Any adverse events or mild or moderate adverse outcomes will be handled by the study physician and serious adverse events will be referred to the study safety committee which may require unblinding of the subjects. 3.1.2.3 Methods of Evaluation 3.1.2.3.1 Primary Outcome Measure 3.1.2.3.1.1 Our primary outcome measure will be a measure of hip-related function which is assessed both objectively by standardized measures and subjectively by questionnaires. 3.1.2.3.1.2 To clarify, 3.1.2.3.1.2 will involve imaging and we will use a combination of 3.1.2.3.1.2.1 X-ray and 3.1.2.3.1.2.2 MRI to assess the effects of the Revision LR femoral stem. 3.1.2.3.2 Secondary Outcome Measures 3.1.2.3.2.1 Secondary outcome measures will include 3.1.2.3.2.1.1 symptoms via questionnaires

model_response: That's OK. Please go on. Where will the study take place?

The sample size required for the clinical trial depends on the effect size, which is represented by power, and the significance level, which is represented by alpha. A power of 80% and an alpha of 5% indicate that the study has 80% power to detect an effect if it is really there, and an effect is actually there 5% of the time by chance. The required sample size depends on too many factors to lay out here (for example, the effect size, the variance, and the correlation between observations). However, one simple formula used in clinical trials estimation is: Sample Size = Z2Xpq/2*[1-beta], where Z is the standard normal distribution with a given α/2, p is the frequency of the disease in the population, and q is the frequency of the disease in the control population, and β is 1-β. In the following example, let's assume we need to detect a difference of standard deviation units between the treatment and control groups, and two-thirds (2/3) of those affected by the disease will be included in the study. This sample size estimation formula is: Sample size = 2[1-(0.66)]=4.3*Z(0.025,2)=127.3. This number of subjects should be randomly selected and stratified 3:1 ratio in order to have 68.5% power to detect a treatment difference of 1-standard deviation unit size in the treatment vs. control groups. With these simple numbers, we could run into problems with large number of subjects needed if the population prevalence is too low. β=1-β=1-0.925=0.075, so we would need about 1273 subjects to have 80% power to detect a treatment effect if it is indeed there.

Recruitment of study participants typically begins at the planning stage of the study, not after IRB review. model_response:
There are many types of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), but the most beneficial might be the one that helps them replace the negative thoughts and feelings associated with smoking with positive affirming ones that are NOT related to smoking. Another helpful approach might be to have them visualize the harmful effects of smoking on their bodies with some type of scale from mild to severe. Then they might visualize themselves with those negative affects reversed. The positive imagery should be more powerful than the negative. It's also important for them to imagine what their lives will be like with the harmful affects of smoking reversed since the urge to smoke will be greatly diminshed when they visualize the changes they have made. When you think of it, they're not really doing the actual affirming, they're just thinking or visualizing - a different approach that's been shown to work well is guided imagery - where you give them the positive affirming and assist them in visualizing the positive affects, which is like you mentioned in your post with an added step which is to talk them through it. I like to give them 3-5 minutes of guided imagery per "session" so that they have time to truly visualize themselves with the effects you've already discussed and others we haven't. But the positive imagery and affirmations should be given throughout and between sessions. 
If you are interested in the DiMe-SALUD2 protocol, let me know. I have found a couple variations that have been used and some that haven't. If you're willing to look into that further, I can give you an update.  What I can suggest though, is to get the protocol written and then have an expert in that protocol conduct a usability study with it before you conduct a clinical trial. You may consider doing a pilot study and using that protocol on a small group of participants before you do that to refine some things too.

It would be helpful to incorporate techniques from motivational interviewing, self-help materials, and psychoeducation. Additionally, you might provide tools to help with stress management and craving suppression. Furthermore, it would be useful to design activities to help with the transition to a non-smoking lifestyle and provide reinforcement and problem solving to address relapse prevention. Phase 3: Test the drug or treatment in a large group of people with the disease or condition, in comparison to the standard treatment, to confirm its effectiveness and safety under widely prevailing conditions. Phase 4: Monitor the drug or treatment in the market after it is approved and distributed, to detect adverse effects unseen during development.

Generally, observational studies are either- Case-control studies Crossover studies Cross-sectional studies Case-control studies: Retrospective records review of patient medical information from subjects with a certain characteristic or disease who are matched with controls who do not have that characteristic or disease. Data sources are usually medical records, bio-specimens, or pharmacy records Crossover studies: Observational studies that follow participants before and after an intervention to evaluate changes in outcomes or exposures Cross-sectional studies: Descriptive analyses of a single time point; information on exposure and outcome status is collected at a single point in time Statistical analyses involving case-control studies depend on binary variables (0/1) for exposure status. Dual nerve blocks have been shown to provide better pain management during shoulder surgery, but there is an increased risk of phrenic nerve paralysis associated with this technique. The phrenic nerve is located near the suprascapular nerve, and in some cases, nerve injury may occur during the block. By combining the suprascapular nerve and superficial cervical plexus block, we can potentially decrease these unintended consequences while maintaining adequate pain relief. This is of particular relevance in high-risk patients or patients with pre-existing lung disease. Our goal is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this approach as compared to single nerve blocks.

Case study - Open design
Ethics of a case study: Should a placebo have been used at all?
Raphamin, a new oral antibiotic, is currently under investigation for its efficacy in the preventive treatment of chronic bacterial cystitis. The study design is a 10-day, randomized single-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial in female patients. Twenty female patients with a confirmed diagnosis of chronic bacterial cystitis were randomized to receive Raphamin or match placebo. Although it is felt that Raphamin provides a great advantage over the current treatments in efficiency and side effect profile, several deaths have occurred in earlier studies in which Raphamin was given to patients with renal insufficiency (creatinine clearance < 60 mL/min). In the present study, only mildly symptomatic patients were enrolled (no fever, no recent UTIs, and no new-onset hematuria). One woman in the Raphamin arm dies of "flu-like symptoms," while another developed seizures and is hospitalized. Subsequent review of the data revealed that 8 of the 18 subjects in the placebo group had mild-to-moderate renal insufficiency (creatinine clearance < 80 mL/min), which should have excluded them from enrollment. The data from the trial are complete and the drug has performed extremely well (76% efficacy). There is controversy about whether the additional lives saved by using Raphamin outweigh the additional lives lost due to renal insufficency.
Raphamin has a good chance of receiving approval by the FDA even with the deaths. The design of the study was appropriate under the circumstances and the IRB felt that the risk- benefit ratio was acceptable. There is also the belief that the data even if the trial were to be redone with an open label design, the results would still be overwhelmingly favorable. The question is, do you think a placebo was ever the right treatment for these patients?

This is particularly important in patients who are considered at high risk for treatment failure, such as those with a high pretreatment PSA level or a higher-grade tumor on the initial FDG-PET.

Sure! The study arms are as follows:
Protocol 1 (Arm 1): All eligible patients with mHSPC undergo an FDG-PET scan to identify any sites of PET-avid disease. Patients with FDG-PET-defined PET-avid disease undergo MDRT until no evidence of PET-avid disease is seen. Patients with ongoing or recurrent PET-avid disease following MDRT and SOC ADT undergo a second FDG-PET scan to document progressive or recurrent disease and subsequently undergo a third form of hormonal treatment or additional MDRT.
Protocol 2 (Arm 2): All eligible patients with mHSPC undergo an FDG-PET scan to identify any sites of PET-avid disease. Patients with FDG-PET-defined PET-avid disease undergo MDRT until disease-free for 6 months. Patients without disease following MDRT and SOC ADT undergo a second FDG-PET scan after 6 months of MDRT to assess disease-free status and subsequently undergo a third form of hormonal management.
All eligible patients with mHSPC are excluded from protocol 2 if FDG-PET scanning reveals disease at any site.
This is a two-group, two-arm, phase III, randomized controlled trial to assess the efficacy of early PET-driven MDRT compared with SOC ADT alone in men with mHSPC. Protocol 1 randomizes men with FDG-PET-defined PET-avid disease to MDRT versus SOC ADT, whereas protocol 2 randomizes men without PET-avid disease to receive either MDRT or SOC ADT. Men randomized to SOC ADT receive the standard, nonrandomized treatment typically provided at the participating investigator center according to the site's preferences.
This clinical research study is powered to detect a statistically significant improvement in overall survival of 24% in protocol 1 and a statistically significant improvement in the 3-year time-to-events such as progression or death from mHSPC of 75% in protocol 2.

The study involves a single group of 30 participants with major depressive disorder, who are randomly assigned to either receive Prozac or a placebo pill for 6 months. The primary outcome measure will be change in scores on a depression scale from baseline to 6 months. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in quality of life, self-esteem, and sleep quality. Participants will be evaluated at baseline, 1 month, and 6 months.
The advantages of this study include a relatively short duration (6 months) and the use of a proven drug with a good safety profile. This type of study would be considered a phase II clinical trial since it would evaluate the safety and efficacy of a single drug in a small group of volunteers.
Control: Observational cohort

Control: Standard treatment +/-, no biopsy - All patients will receive standard treatment as for sarcoidosis, but without peripheral airway biopsy.

This arm will help determine the incremental value of peripheral airway biopsy, and any potential harms associated with it, by documenting the rate of false positive and negative results. In addition, this arm will help stratify patients who may benefit the most from this procedure based on their clinical presentation.

2.0 Clinical Trial Phases
The different clinical trial phases depend on the aim of the trial and the way in which the treatment under investigation is meant to be used. 
The clinical trial phase descriptions are as follows:

Stage 0 (Phase 0): Include studies such as pilot studies and studies that investigate pharmacokinetics. A single dose is given to a small number of healthy subjects, and pharmacokinetics of this dose are studied.
Stage 1 (Phase 1): Include studies that involve a limited number of subjects who receive the drug for the first time. Monitoring of very low doses to rule out severe drug toxicity is also done here.
Stage 2 (Phase 2): This phase involves a limited treatment course of increasing doses of the drug, with a main focus on safety and dosage.  Effects on a disease target are observed.
Stage 3 (Phase 3): this phase involves a larger number of subjects who receive the investigated drug for the first time.  Outcomes are monitored, and side effects are documented.
Stage 4 (Phase 4): also known as post-marketing surveillance. This phase involves patients who are treated with the drug in every-day clinical practice to monitor the long-term side effects of the drug.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_trial#Clinical_trial_phases

model_response: Part A - Escalation would include a smaller number of participants to test safety and tolerability of the combination therapy, while also determining the recommended dose to move forward to the next phase. Part B - Expansion would include a larger number of participants in order to evaluate the combination therapy's efficacy and to further confirm safety and tolerability.

In Part B, we will expand the treatment to additional patients who received previous treatment for advanced NSCLC. Our goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab in patients with metastatic NSCLC. This arm will help us to confirm our findings from Part A with a larger patient population.

In Part A - Escalation, Tepotinib will be given orally at dose levels of 30, 40, and 50 mg. Pembrolizumab will also be administered orally every 3 weeks at dose levels of 200, 300, and 400 mg. The combination will be administered until there is confirmed disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

In Part B - Expansion, patients will receive similar treatment of Tepotinib plus Pembrolizumab as in Part A, but at a higher dose and for a longer period. The duration of treatment is expected to be sixteen weeks. This phase of the trial will involve a larger number of patients and allow us to assess the safety and efficacy of this combination treatment in a larger population of patients with NSCLC.

Control Group: Preferably, individuals with idiopathic scoliosis without post-COVHID-19. However, age, gender, and body mass index restrictions will be considered if necessary. Number of Participants: This study is designed to have 40 participants. Measures: Primary Outcome Measures - The main outcome measure in the current study is quality of life as assessed by the Short Scoliosis Research Society (SRS) quality of life questionnaire. Methods of Analysis: The statistical methods used in the present study will be inferential at a sig. of 0.05 Alpha level. Hypotheses:
H0: SOT201 has no efficacy in the treatment of advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The null hypothesis is that SOT201 has no additional efficacy above standard of care when used as a monotherapy for advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The alternative hypothesis is that SOT201 has efficacy in advanced or metastatic solid tumors. 
H1: SOT201 has significant efficacy in the treatment of advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The null hypothesis is that SOT201 has no additional efficacy when used as a monotherapy for advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The alternative hypothesis is that SOT201 has significance efficacy in advanced or metastatic solid tumors. 
Objectives: To determine if SOT201 can improve the progression-free survival in patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors. 
- Time Frame: Up to 2 years 6 months

Objectives: To assess side effects and safety profile of SOT201 compared to standard of care in the treatment of advanced or metastatic solid tumors.

was initiated in June of 2007 to test the hypothesis that low-dose bortezomib would prevent disease progression while tolerable with acceptable toxicity. To assess the hypothesis, the number of participants diagnosed with active multiple myeloma within 2 years is the primary efficacy endpoint. Secondary endpoints include blood tests, bone scans, and quality of life. The adaptive design and safety monitoring will facilitate evaluation of potential dose level reduction or discontinuation if toxicity or other unfavorable events occur [14].
Participants with SBMM with symptoms of myeloma [15], elevated concentration of serum M protein > 3.5 g/dL, no active organ damage, and 10-15% bone marrow plasma cells are eligible to enroll. SBMM is defined as abnormal serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) or 2 of the following abnormal serum free light chains (FLC): SFLC-1 > 20 mg/dL, SFLC-2 > 300 mg/dL, or SFLC-3 > 200 mg/dL, absence of lytic bone lesions, and absence of hyper-calcemia [16].
Participants are randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio of bortezomib to placebo. All participants assigned to bortezomib receive escalating doses of 0.6, 1.2, and 2.4 mg/m2 weekly. Bortezomib will be infused subcutaneously on days 1, 8, and 15 of every 28-day cycle. Participants will complete three cycles of treatment before the drug can be discontinued due to lack of efficacy or intolerable toxicity. Blood tests are done weekly during the first cycle of treatment and every 2 weeks thereafter. Bone scans are done with whole body dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) every 3 months [17]. At day 11 of cycles 3 and 5 of treatment, all participants are given bortezomib and treated with a single intravenous (IV) inf

In the "Experimental: Expansion (Part 2)" arm, investigators will study the safety and efficacy of linvoseltamab in participants with smoldering multiple myeloma who meet the following criteria: have an M-protein level of greater than 3.5 grams per deciliter, have a monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance that was detected within 36 months, are asymptomatic based on a Lent score of zero, and have no history of blast crises or treatment with a bortezomib-containing regimen. Participants will receive linvoseltamab every three weeks for 24 weeks. Those assigned to the control arm will receive a placebo drug. Clinicians won't know which participants receive the active drug until the end of the study. The primary endpoint of the study will be the percentage of participants who experience disease progression, defined as symptomatic transformation, the presence of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, serum M-protein level greater than 3.5 g/dL, or multiple end-organ involvement. Secondary endpoints include progression-free survival, response rate, and time to disease progression. Other clinical, laboratory, and biomarker assessments will be evaluated throughout the study.

For this study, we need to observe the feasibility and acceptability of Connect-Home Plus among a relatively small group of participants before scaling up the intervention to a larger group. Therefore, the single-arm, post-test-only design best reflects the study intent. Additionally, a post-test only design is appropriate for an exploratory, phase-I evaluation of intervention feasibility. The Connect-Home Plus intervention was developed and tested in a previous randomized clinical trial, so the study team is familiar with the materials and procedures. However, while we have a good understanding of its risks and benefits, unexpected issues could arise during this feasibility and acceptability assessment. In the absence of a concurrent control group, this design will help us capture such surprises and make necessary adjustments. Finally, a post-test only assessment better matches the clinical approach of Connect-Home Plus, which focuses on enhancing patient discharge processes and not on improving clinical outcomes.

Arm 3: Control Arm: Care as Usual/Usual Care
Control Arm/Comparator: Control Arm: Usual care will be provided to all eligible patients at the skilled nursing facility during and after their stay. This includes usual level of care provided by the long-term care facility, as well as referrals and follow-up support available within the community. Clinical activities will be conducted by the usual care team but will not be linked to the Connect-Home Program to assess whether the approach improves care. Usual care provides evidence of the standard or typical method of care typically received by participants in this disease state and without the application of the new method. This serves as the control for the comparison of intervention to no intervention.

Because patients with osteosarcoma have a variety of treatment options and because the optimal therapy is strongly influenced by the stage at diagnosis, it is important to provide a general summary of the treatment phases for each disease stage. General Treatment Strategies for the Initial Management of Metastatic Osteosarcoma The decision to perform surgery in a patient with metastatic osteosarcoma depends on several factors including the patient’s performance status, location and extent of the metastasis, prior therapy, and presence of any significant comorbid conditions.  If the performance status is good and the tumor is detected at one site, surgery and chemotherapeutic therapy is the first line of treatment.  If the tumor is detected at several sites, the main goals of the initial approach can include pain control and stabilization of the neuro-musculoskeletal system to avoid surgical complications and maintain function. Radiation to the primary tumor site as well as to sites of active metastasis and any sites of active disease may be considered. This approach is mainly used for patients with unresectable disease (e.g., pelvic or rib involvement). If there is doubt about the exact size, location, and extent of metastases, staging studies such as a computed tomopraphy (CT) scan may be helpful.  After induction therapy, the main goal of therapy in patients with disease limited to bone is complete resection. If there are multiple sites of disease, neoadjuvant chemotherapy may be considered to obtain a complete tumor necrosis or control of locally advanced disease before surgery. Radiation may also be used to treat persistent disease after surgery.
If the patient is not a candidate for surgery, initial treatment involves a combination of chemotherapy and radiation.  Neoadjuvant or concurrent chemotherapy and radiation are used if feasible. If not, the initial treatment can be sequential chemotherapy and radiation.  Chemotherapy is typically administered until the lesions have shrunk

1. Waste Outcomes: Renal Function Change after Vitamin B6 Intervention
Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is used to treat a variety of conditions, including sepsis. Sepsis is a serious medical condition characterized by a bacterial infection which can cause organ dysfunction. In some cases, the infection can lead to kidney damage. This is a randomized controlled trial to examine the relationship between administering high-dose intravenous vitamin B6 and renal function change in patients with sepsis. Eligible participants will be randomized into two equal groups - one group which receives vitamin B6 and one which receives a saline solution. The primary outcome measure will be the change in renal function. Key dates:
Recruitment begins: February 2020
Recruitment ends: February 2023
Data cleaning and analysis: March 2023
Presentation at conference: June 2024
Peer reviewed publication: September 2024

model_response: Well, observational studies are generally done in one of two phases: case-control or cohort. In a case-control study, you enroll patients with the outcome of interest and compare them to a control group of patients without the outcome. In a cohort study, you follow patients without the outcome and then observe who develops the outcome over time. Both of these phases can be observational or interventional, so you could run a case-control or cohort study with an interventional phase. For example, you could enroll patients with coronary artery stenosis and observe who gets an angiogram with a significant stenosis and then follow-up on those patients to see how their outcomes differ from those without significant stenosis. Let's talk more about the interventional aspects of the study.

To create your own protocol statement, follow these steps:
Write down the goals of your clinical protocol. What are you trying to investigate, prove, or confirm? What question(s) will this study aim to answer?
Outline the methods of data collection and analysis. What procedures will you use to gather data and how will you organize and interpret it?
Describe the participants. What population will you work with, and what inclusion and exclusion criteria will you apply?
Describe the intervention. How will the treatment regimen work?
Outline the risks and benefits of the study procedures. What are the possible risks and consequences of the treatments or tests you'll use?
Describe the anticipated timeline of the study. When and how will you contact participants, gather data, and deliver results?
Write a draft of the clinical protocol. Leave everything detailed and don't skip any steps. Add or remove elements as needed, but make sure to keep the overall structure and purpose of the document intact.
Edit the protocol statement, and have it proofread and critiqued by others. A fresh set of eyes can help you spot hidden errors or omissions in your protocol.
What are the aims and objectives of a clinical protocol statement?
The key goals of a clinical protocol statement are to provide the necessary steps for a clinical study, outline the procedures for data collection and analysis, describe the participants and the intervention, and outline the potential risks and benefits of the study.
What are the components of a clinical protocol statement?
A clinical protocol statement should include an introduction, aims and objectives, participant criteria, methods of data collection and analysis, intervention, potential risks and benefits, and a timeline.
What should you include in the introduction of a clinical protocol statement?
The introduction to a clinical protocol statement should include the study hypotheses and justification, brief background information on the need for the study, and the study design and methods being used.
